info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued January 06 at 6:03AM PST by NWS Pendleton
info.description: ...A SIGNIFICANT PATTERN CHANGE IS IN STORE THIS UPCOMING WEEK... ...A PERIOD OF HEAVY MOUNTAIN SNOW IS POSSIBLE TUESDAY INTO WEDNESDAY... ...COLDER TEMPERATURES BY THE END OF THE WEEK... After a very warm December and start to January, a significant weather pattern change is in store this upcoming week. The week will start out relatively mild, but a storm will affect the region beginning Tuesday and continue into Wednesday. A cold front will cross the region and abundant moisture will bring heavy mountain snow to the Cascades and Blue Mountains beginning Tuesday and continue into Wednesday. One to two feet of snow is possible above 2500 feet, with locally higher amounts. The cold front will also cause about a 10 degree drop in temperatures between Tuesday and Wednesday Additionally, it will be breezy to windy on Tuesday, especially in the morning, with wind gusts greater than 50 mph across the Cascade Gaps and Columbia Basin and wind gusts greater than 30 mph in most locations. Wind gusts will decrease during the day but still remain above 30 mph. These winds will cause blowing and drifting of snow. Anyone with travel plans over the Cascade passes or Blue Mountains should be prepared for dangerous travel conditions due to a combination of heavy snow and blowing snow. By Friday into next weekend, while there is still considerable uncertainty, there is the potential for the coldest temperatures of this winter season. Model guidance varies substantially at this point and confidence is low (25 to 30%). However, there is the possibility that high temperatures may not get above freezing, with overnight lows in the teens. Since the potential cold temperatures are about a week away, please monitor the forecast for potential changes, updates and additional updates over the next several days.
